‘Don’t leave, Pyotr Petrovitch,’ Dounia said. ‘You planned to stay the evening. Plus, you mentioned wanting to talk with Mom.’ 

‘Exactly, Avdotya Romanovna,’ Pyotr Petrovitch replied seriously, sitting back down but still holding his hat. ‘I did want to discuss something important with you and your respected mother. However, since your brother can’t be straightforward about Mr. Svidrigaïlov’s proposals in front of me, I also can’t speak openly about serious matters here… in front of others. Besides, my crucial request has been ignored…’ 

He looked all hurt and went silent, acting dignified. 

‘The reason my brother was here is that I insisted he be present,’ Dounia said. ‘You wrote that you felt insulted by him; we need to clear this up right away, and you both should make amends. If Rodya did insult you, he should apologize.’ 

Pyotr Petrovitch took a firmer stance. ‘Some insults, Avdotya Romanovna, are too deep to just forget. There’s a line you can’t cross; once you do, there’s no going back.’ 

‘That’s not what I meant, Pyotr Petrovitch,’ Dounia interjected, a bit impatiently. ‘You need to realize that our whole future hinges on whether…’

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Dounia insists on addressing the insults between her brother and Pyotr Petrovitch to reconcile and secure their future.
